message.content:
We can “build” an inventory balance by “adding” up every purchase (which “adds” inventory) and “reducing” inventory by the cost‐amount recorded on every sale (i.e. the cost of goods “sold” from inventory). In the data below no “initial” inventory (apart from the “Initial” bank/cash/fixed‑asset entries) contains any “inventory” and so we take the beginning inventory as zero.

Step 1. Sum all the purchase amounts (the “Purchase” transactions only). Using the table the “Purchase” entries are (with the “amount” value):

 • Purchase20231231001: 100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231002: 60,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231003: 15,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231004: 100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231005: 100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231006: 100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231007: 5,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231008: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231009: 15,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231010: 300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231011: 10,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231012: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231013: 1,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231014: 15,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231015: 3,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231016: 2,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231017: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231018: 60,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231019: 2,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231020: 3,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231021: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231022: 10,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231023: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231024: 20,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231025: 5,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231026: 300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231027: 40,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231028: 3,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231029: 15,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231030: 2,000.00  

When we sum the above amounts we obtain a total purchases value of 1,486,000.00.

Step 2. Sum the “cost_amount” field on every “Sale” transaction (in the sale rows the “cost_amount” is recorded as the cost “taken out” of inventory). The “Sale” rows list the following cost_amount (in the order they appear):

 • 100,000.00; then 20,000.00; 20,000.00; 20,000.00; 5,000.00; 5,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 5,000.00; 20,000.00; 20,000.00; 100,000.00; 5,000.00; 20,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 1,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 1,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 1,000.00; 100,000.00; 5,000.00; 1,000.00; 20,000.00; 20,000.00; 1,000.00; 5,000.00; 1,000.00; 20,000.00; 20,000.00; 5,000.00; 20,000.00; 100,000.00; 1,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 1,000.00; 5,000.00; 100,000.00; 20000.00; 5000.00; 1000.00; 20000.00; 5000.00; 5000.00; … and so on.

When all these “cost_amount” values are added the sum comes to 1,287,000.00.

Step 3. (a) Before any transactions were recorded the inventory (of inventory‐typed items) was zero – that is, Inventory Initial Value = 0.00.

(b) The Inventory End Value is calculated as:
  Inventory End = (Total Purchases) – (Cost of Goods Sold)
           = 1,486,000.00 – 1,287,000.00
           = 199,000.00

Thus, the resulting answers are:

Inventory Initial Value: 0.00  
Inventory End Value: 199000.00

The answer is then presented as requested:

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Inventory Initial Value": "0.00", "Inventory End Value": "199000.00"} }
``` 

This concludes the step‐by‐step solution.
